--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Ilja Preuss" <preuss@d...> wrote:
> 
> I find that writing tests helps me a lot thinking about the design,
so I'm
> not a fan of switching my design brain off while writing tests. I'm
not sure
> why you would want to do that.
> 

I didn't. Somebody else did when they asked the question that started
this thread. But I would contend that there must be something wrong
with the practice of TDD that leads to the conclusion that the tests
do not adequately cover the code and the only way to get adequate
coverage is to make methods public.

> > Given that context, my mind hasn't
> > changed. If the private method is already tested through an
> > existing public method then you don't need to do anything. In
> > fact, exposing the method and writing an explicit test against it is
> > duplication. 
> 
> Unless the tests of the already existing public method can be
simplified in
> consequence.

The duplication is that there will now be two tests for exactly the
same thing. One through the original public method (which you will
still want to test, no?) and another for the originally private
method. The method (nee private) is now tested twice.

> I'm confused, because TDD is much more a design practice than a testing
> practice. Anyway, I don't think I proposed anything as "a solution
per se",
> but said that it would be one of the first things I'd think about,
and that
> I very often find that I find a solution I like when I do so.

I agree that TDD is more about design than testing. My point is that
working TDD I wouldn't think about this at all because I wouldn't
write any code without a test. I wouldn't refactor until I got to
green. Private methods wouldn't exist unless they were born through
refactoring. I don't implement new features while refactoring. As a
result I don't spend time thinking about how to test private methods
unless I'm responding to threads on the JUnit Yahoo! group. ;-)

> A private method that is complex enough to need explicite testing
simply is
> a hint to a class that has too many responsibilities and has lost
cohesion.
> A class that has just one responsibility is quite unlikely to be
complex,
> let alone have complex private methods.

As I said, this doesn't seem to happen to me. I'm not sure where we're
doing things differently. Maybe it's more a hint that the developer is
taking steps that are too big? I don't think %LOC in private methods
is a decent metric for measuring cohesion. But then I haven't read
Michael Feather's blog yet.

> > Maybe Martin Fowler wasn't wearing his Tester hat at the
> > time. Maybe he was and wanted to write a book about how to
> > produce better designs, not about solving problems with unit
> > tests.
> 
> If I remember correctly, he put a chapter about Code Smells in the
book -
> about hints in the code that you should refactor. Well, I think that a
> private method that needs explicite testing is such a smell.

Which one(s)?

> > So, third maybe in a row, maybe refactorings shouldn't
> > be viewed as ways to solve problems with your the test suite?
> 
> If your design is in the way while writing tests, it looks like a design
> problem to me. So I don't see why we should exclude refactoring as a
viable
> solution.

I'm not convinced it's a design problem. How can the design be in the
way while writing tests if there *is* no design until you write the
tests? How is it your design and implementation exist *before* the tests? 

> > Or, maybe it would be an interesting topic to write an
> > article on -- how to apply refactorings when your focus is testing
> > and not design. 
> 
> I really have problems following this whole notion of "focus on
testing" as
> something that excludes thinking about design. It's just not the way
I work,
> I guess.

Conversely, I have problems following the notion that practicing TDD I
could get to place that was so bad in my design that I start
refactoring just so that I can test properly. Unless the code exists
when I start writing the tests ...

Jim
